panels.title: Compression level and failure rate threshold

panels.description: The level of zlib compression to use for InnoDB compressed tables and indexes.
panels.title: InnoDB Compression level

panels.description: The compression failure rate threshold for a table
panels.title: InnoDB Compression Failure Threshold

panels.description: The maximum percentage that can be reserved as free space within each compressed page, allowing room to reorganize the data and modification log within the page when a compressed table or index is updated and the data might be recompressed.
panels.title: Compression Failure Rate Threshold

panels.description: Specifies whether images of re-compressed pages are written to the redo log. Re-compression may occur when changes are made to compressed data.
panels.title: Write Pages to The Redo Log

panels.description: Number of compression operations attempted. Pages are compressed whenever an empty page is created or the space for the uncompressed modification log runs out.
panels.title: Compress Attempts

panels.description: Number of uncompression operations performed. Compressed InnoDB pages are uncompressed whenever compression fails, or the first time a compressed page is accessed in the buffer pool and the uncompressed page does not exist.
panels.title: Uncompressed Attempts

panels.description:
Shows the ratio between Success InnoDB Compress vs the total InnoDB Compress operations. A high ration indicates that InnoDB compression is being effective and helping to save disk space.

See also:

links.title: Using the Compression Information Schema Tables

panels.title: Compression Success Ratio

panels.description:
Shows the time in seconds spent by InnoDB Compression operations.

See also:

links.title: Using the Compression Information Schema Tables

targets.expr:
avg by (service_name) ((sum(rate(mysql_info_schema_innodb_cmp_compress_time_seconds_total{service_name=~"$service_name"}[$interval])) by (service_name) or
sum(irate(mysql_info_schema_innodb_cmp_compress_time_seconds_total{service_name=~"$service_name"}[5m])) by (service_name))) /
sum(count(node_cpu_seconds_total{mode="user", node_name=~"$node_name"}) by (node_name)) *100

panels.title: CPU Core Usage for Compression

panels.description:
Shows the time in seconds spent by InnoDB Uncompression operations.

See also:

links.title: Using the Compression Information Schema Tables

targets.expr:
avg by (node_name) ((sum(rate(mysql_info_schema_innodb_cmp_uncompress_time_seconds_total{service=~"$service_name"}[$interval])) by (service_name) or
sum(irate(mysql_info_schema_innodb_cmp_uncompress_time_seconds_total{instance=~"$service_name"}[5m])) by (service_name))) /
sum(count(node_cpu_seconds_total{mode="user", node_name=~"$node_name"}) by (node_name)) * 100

panels.title: CPU Core Usage for Uncompression

panels.description:
Shows the total amount of used compressed pages into the InnoDB Buffer Pool split by page size.

See also:

links.title: Using the Compression Information Schema Tables

panels.title: Total Used Pages

panels.description:
Shows the total amount of free compressed pages into the InnoDB Buffer Pool split by page size.

See also:

links.title: Using the Compression Information Schema Tables

panels.title: Total Free Pages

panels.description:
Shows the amount of used compressed pages into this InnoDB Buffer Pool instance split by page size.

See also:

links.title: Using the Compression Information Schema Tables

panels.title: Used Pages (Buffer Pull $buffer)

panels.description:
Shows the amount of free compressed pages into this InnoDB Buffer Pool instance split by page size.

See also:

links.title: Using the Compression Information Schema Tables

panels.title: Pages Free (Buffer Pull $buffer)

panels.description:
**InnoDB Buffer Pool Size **

InnoDB maintains a storage area called the buffer pool for caching data and indexes in memory.  Knowing how the InnoDB buffer pool works, and taking advantage of it to keep frequently accessed data in memory, is one of the most important aspects of MySQL tuning. The goal is to keep the working set in memory. In most cases, this should be between 60%-90% of available memory on a dedicated database host, but depends on many factors.

links.title: Tuning the InnoDB Buffer Pool Size

panels.title: Buffer Pool Size

panels.description:
**InnoDB Buffer Pool Size % of Total RAM**

InnoDB maintains a storage area called the buffer pool for caching data and indexes in memory.  Knowing how the InnoDB buffer pool works, and taking advantage of it to keep frequently accessed data in memory, is one of the most important aspects of MySQL tuning. The goal is to keep the working set in memory. In most cases, this should be between 60%-90% of available memory on a dedicated database host, but depends on many factors.

links.title: Tuning the InnoDB Buffer Pool Size

panels.title: Buffer Pool Size of Total RAM

panels.description: Number of Innodb Log Files Multiplied by Their Size
panels.title: Total Redo Log Space

targets.expr:
avg by (service_name) ((max_over_time(mysql_global_status_innodb_checkpoint_age{service_name=~"$service_name"}[$interval]) or 
max_over_time(mysql_global_status_innodb_checkpoint_age{service_name=~"$service_name"}[5m]) or
max_over_time(mysql_info_schema_innodb_metrics_recovery_log_lsn_checkpoint_age_total{service_name=~"$service_name"}[$interval]) or
max_over_time(mysql_info_schema_innodb_metrics_recovery_log_lsn_checkpoint_age_total{service_name=~"$service_name"}[5m]) or
max_over_time(mysql_info_schema_innodb_metrics_log_log_lsn_checkpoint_age{service_name=~"$service_name"}[$interval]) or
max_over_time(mysql_info_schema_innodb_metrics_log_log_lsn_checkpoint_age{service_name=~"$service_name"}[5m])) / (max_over_time(mysql_global_status_innodb_checkpoint_max_age{service_name=~"$service_name"}[$interval]) or
max_over_time(mysql_global_status_innodb_checkpoint_max_age{service_name=~"$service_name"}[5m]) or
max_over_time(mysql_info_schema_innodb_metrics_recovery_log_max_modified_age_async{service_name=~"$service_name"}[$interval]) or
max_over_time(mysql_info_schema_innodb_metrics_recovery_log_max_modified_age_async{service_name=~"$service_name"}[5m]) or
max_over_time(mysql_info_schema_innodb_metrics_log_log_max_modified_age_async{service_name=~"$service_name"}[$interval]) or
max_over_time(mysql_info_schema_innodb_metrics_log_log_max_modified_age_async{service_name=~"$service_name"}[5m])))

panels.description: Amount of Data Read and Written to Innodb Data Files
panels.title: Data Bandwidth

panels.description: Percent of Active Sections which are blocked due to waiting on Innodb Row Locks
panels.title: Row Lock Blocking

panels.description: The parameter shows how long a system has been “up” and running without a shut down or restart.
panels.title: System Uptime

panels.description: The system load is a measurement of the computational work the system is performing. Each running process either using or waiting for CPU resources adds 1 to the load.
panels.title: Load Average

panels.description: RAM (Random Access Memory) is the hardware in a computing device where the operating system, application programs and data in current use are kept so they can be quickly reached by the device's processor.
panels.title: RAM

panels.description:
Percent of Memory Available
Note: on Modern Linux Kernels amount of Memory Available for application is not the same as Free+Cached+Buffers
panels.title: Memory Available

panels.description: RAM + SWAP
panels.title: Virtual Memory

panels.description: Sum of disk space on all partitions. Note  it can be significantly over-reported in some installations
panels.title: Disk Space

panels.description: Lowest percent of the disk space available
panels.title: Min Space Available

panels.description: The CPU time is measured in clock ticks or seconds. It is useful to measure CPU time as a percentage of the CPU's capacity, which is called the CPU usage.

targets.expr: avg by (node_name,mode) (clamp_max(((avg by (mode) ( (clamp_max(rate(node_cpu_seconds_total{node_name=~"$node_name",mode!="idle"}[$interval]),1)) or (clamp_max(irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{node_name=~"$node_name",mode!="idle"}[5m]),1)) ))*100 or (avg_over_time(node_cpu_average{node_name=~"$node_name", mode!="total", mode!="idle"}[$interval]) or avg_over_time(node_cpu_average{node_name=~"$node_name", mode!="total", mode!="idle"}[5m]))),100))

panels.title: CPU Usage

panels.description: When a system is running with maximum CPU utilization, the transmitting and receiving threads must all share the available CPU. This will cause data to be queued more frequently to cope with the lack of CPU. CPU Saturation may be measured as the length of a wait queue, or the time spent waiting on the queue.
panels.title: CPU Saturation and Max Core Usage

panels.description:
Disk I/O includes read or write or input/output operations involving a physical disk. It is the speed with which the data transfer takes place between the hard disk drive and RAM.

Swap Activity is memory management that involves swapping sections of memory to and from physical storage.
panels.title: Disk I/O and Swap Activity

panels.description: Network traffic refers to the amount of data moving across a network at a given point in time.
panels.title: Network Traffic
